channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Netanyahu Appears to Rebuff Blinken’s Request for Humanitarian Pauses
item.description: Israel’s leader, Benjamin Netanyahu, said any cease-fire would need to be contingent on the release of hostages. And in Lebanon, the leader of Hezbollah stopped short of declaring war on Israel.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: A power outage in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Sends Biggest Drone Barrage in Weeks, Ukrainian Officials Say
item.description: Army officials and military analysts say it is part of a campaign to wear down and probe Ukrainian air defenses ahead of winter.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The site of a drone strike early on Friday in Kharkiv, in northeastern Ukraine.

item.title: As Gaza War Enters New Phase, Israel Faces Pressure Over Civilian Deaths
item.description: Fears are rising that the conflict could spread to the occupied West Bank, where tensions are soaring among Palestinians angered over deadly Israeli airstrikes in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers working at an artillery unit near the Gaza border with Netivot, Israel, on Thursday.

item.title: As a Teen, She Loved Video Games. Now She’s Using A.I. to Try to Quash Malaria.
item.description: Rokhaya Diagne, a 25-year-old A.I. entrepreneur in Senegal, is part of a subset of Africa’s enormous youth population that is confident technology can solve the continent’s biggest problems.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rokhaya Diagne, 25, a computer science major in Senegal, has channeled her teenage love for video games into a new passion: using artificial intelligence to help eradicate malaria.

item.title: Japan and Philippines, Wary of China, Look to Expand Military Ties
item.description: An agreement, driven by the shared view that Beijing increasingly poses a threat to the region, would give Tokyo access to bases and make it easier to conduct joint drills.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan, seated, at the presidential palace in Manila on Friday, where he met with President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. of the Philippines.

item.title: Politics and Particulates: New Delhi Fights Against Pollution
item.description: Schools shut down and residents were told to stay indoors as the government seems unable to avert an airborne calamity with multiple culprits that descends at the onset of winter.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Traffic in New Delhi on Friday. Despite the attempts to mitigate the effects of the pollution, there was little immediate relief for the city’s many millions of residents.

item.title: Somewhat Guiltily, Ukrainians Miss Matthew Perry
item.description: Even as the war’s devastation rages on, Ukrainians have found space to mourn an actor who brought them comfort and laughter.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: NBCU Photo Bank, via Getty Images
item.media:description: From left, Courteney Cox, Matthew Perry, Jennifer Aniston and Matt LeBlanc in a scene from “Friends.” Mr. Perry, who played Chandler Bing on the popular sitcom, died on Oct. 28. He was 54.

item.title: Fire at Drug Rehab Center in Iran Kills at Least 32, State Media Report
item.description: A local official reportedly said the center’s manager had been arrested, and he blamed overcrowding at the facility for the high toll.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd

item.title: An American evacuates to Egypt: ‘Let’s just hope we can make it.’
item.description: Lena Beseiso was one of 400 Americans approved to cross the Rafah border on Thursday. We followed her journey into Egypt.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik

item.title: N.F.L., on Lookout for Growth, Finds Open Arms in Germany
item.description: Football was introduced to the country by U.S. soldiers after World War II, but interests soared when the N.F.L. played its first regular-season game there last year.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The audience’s knowledge and enthusiasm at a taping last month of “Prime Time Football Live” was a sign of the N.F.L.’s rising stature in Germany.

item.title: Russia Pulled Out of a Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. Here’s What That Means.
item.description: In de-ratifying the agreement, Moscow removed another brick in the wall of formal arms control intended to limit proliferation.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: The Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, left, shaking hands with President Ronald Reagan at a conference in Geneva in November 1985.

item.title: China’s Male Leaders Push to Get Women to Stay Home for Family
item.description: The Communist Party’s solution to the country’s demographic crisis and a slowing economy is to push women back into traditional roles.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Leaders of the Chinese Communist Party and the state, including Xi Jinping, attending the 13th National Women’s Congress in Beijing last month.

item.title: ‘More Than Just Rugby’: Championship Generates Harmony in South Africa
item.description: South Africans are savoring a second consecutive World Cup victory, producing a racial unity that even Hollywood couldn’t make up and an escape from the country’s troubles.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: South African rugby fans savored a second consecutive World Cup championship, meeting the returning victors at the Johannesburg airport on Tuesday.

item.title: In Misinformation Over Israel-Gaza War, Images From Past Conflicts Can Undercut True Toll
item.description: Videos and photos of the conflict are competing with misappropriated depictions of unrelated tragedies, a cycle that experts say diminishes the experiences of victims past and present.
item.dc:creator: Angelo Fichera
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Photographers in Sderot, Israel, overlooking the border with Gaza this week. Photos and videos taken out of context are a common form of misinformation online.

item.title: Flooding in Tuscany Leaves Five Dead
item.description: Storm Ciaran swept into Italy with torrential rains overnight, continuing its deadly push across Western Europe.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: People cleaning the street in Montemurlo, Italy, on Friday after heavy rains overnight.

item.title: Is Fluminense the Team of the Future?
item.description: A soccer revolution started with a text message, but the broader game wants proof. A win in the Copa Libertadores final on Saturday might provide it.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Fluminense will face Boca Juniors in the Copa Libertadores final on Saturday.

item.title: Biden Hosts Leaders of South American Nations for an Economic Summit
item.description: One goal is to help bolster economies of countries across the region so they can better absorb the millions of migrants who are fleeing poverty, political instability and natural disasters.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden hosted leaders from 11 Western countries to address immigration and the economy.

item.title: Headwind Cycling Race Called Off Over Too Much Wind
item.description: Storm Ciarán, which has battered Western Europe this week, proved too much for a quirky Dutch cycling competition.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Participants in a previous headwind cycling race brave gusts on their bicycles.

item.title: Hezbollah’s Leader Stops Short of Calling to Expand Gaza War
item.description: In his first public comments during the Gaza war, Hassan Nasrallah said his powerful Lebanese militia had tied up Israel forces to help Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, seen onscreen in Beirut’s southern suburbs on Friday.

item.title: After a 40-Year Wait, Trap Shooter Leonel Martínez Returns to the Olympics
item.description: Leonel Martínez, a trap shooter from Venezuela, left the Summer Games in 1984 without making the podium. At 60, he’s again vying for a medal.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and Victor Mather
item.media:description: Leonel Martínez qualified for Venezuela’s Olympic team last week. He will return to the Games next year in Paris, after a 40-year Olympic drought.

item.title: To Wear the Sudoku Crown, One Must Solve Any Number of Puzzles
item.description: Also helpful: pens, pencils, earplugs, plushies, a water bottle, calming herbal oil and the occasional “wild bifurcation” (a.k.a. a wild guess).
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts and Chloë Ellingson
item.media:credit: Chloe Ellingson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tantan Dai of China, front left, on the second day of the World Sudoku Championship in Toronto.

item.title: A Giant Leap for the Leap Second. Is Mankind Ready?
item.description: A top scientist has proposed a new way to reconcile the two different ways that our clocks keep time. Meet — wait for it — the leap minute.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.category: International Bureau of Weights and Measures
National Institute of Standards and Technology
item.media:credit: Kyodo News Stills, via Getty Images
item.media:description: People gathered to observe a leap second in 2012 outside the National Institute of Information and Communications Technology in Tokyo.

item.title: As Cars Have Grown Bigger, Parking Spaces Might, Too
item.description: Australians are grumbling about a recent invasion of American-style giant pickup trucks. But even before that, vehicle sizes were increasing.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: Fred and Hannah for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cars parked in Hobart, Australia.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Israeli troops enter Gaza City.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings in northern Gaza seen from Sderot, Israel, on Thursday.

item.title: The Laws of War Have Limits. What Does That Mean for the Hamas-Israel War?
item.description: For many readers, the events of the past few weeks have raised profound and vexing questions that can illustrate the limits and strengths of international law.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague in 2022. Investigations of war crimes and crimes against humanity often take years to complete, and don’t necessarily lead to criminal charges.

item.title: U.S. Drones Are Flying Over Gaza to Aid in Hostage Recovery, Officials Say
item.description: The military has been sending weapons and advisers to Israel, but the flights suggest a more active American role.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen and Eric Schmitt

item.title: Islamic Art Exhibition Postponed in Pittsburgh Amid Israel-Hamas War
item.description: The Frick Pittsburgh cited fears that the show could become “a source of unintended insensitivity or offense.”
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.media:description: The Frick Pittsburgh, where a planned traveling exhibition surveying 10 centuries of Islamic Art was postponed because of the Israel-Hamas war.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Interviews Elon Musk on Perils and Benefits of A.I.
item.description: The prime minister’s conversation with the tech billionaire was part of an effort this week to present Britain as a leader in artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain and Elon Musk in London on Thursday.

item.title: Why the Atlantic Jet Stream Is Helping Some Flights Arrive Early
item.description: Flights traveling west to east over the Atlantic Ocean this week have had the wind on their side, pushing some landing times up to an hour ahead of schedule.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: A British Airways flight from New York to London was among eastbound international flights that have arrived early recently, because the jet stream over the Atlantic Ocean increased their speeds.

item.title: Gaza Doctor Describes ‘Horrific Scenes’ After Israeli Airstrikes on Jabaliya
item.description: Gazans under bombardment say there is a surge of severely injured children entering hospitals, doctors operating without anesthesia and morgues overflowing with bodies.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Karen Zraick
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Days of Israeli airstrikes caused widespread destruction in Gaza’s Jabaliya neighborhood.

item.title: Israeli Troops Encircle Gaza City as Global Criticism of Strikes Mounts
item.description: An Israeli military spokesman said that Israeli soldiers had surrounded Gaza’s largest city. White House officials said they would urge Israel to “pause” its bombardment on humanitarian grounds.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller and Aaron Boxerman
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: People search for casualties in the Gaza neighborhood of Jabaliya on Thursday following Israeli airstrikes over the previous few days.

item.title: Dagestan Riot Against Plane From Israel Was Weeks in the Making
item.description: A New York Times analysis of local Telegram channels showed posts falsely claiming Israeli refugees were incoming had been shared long before the antisemitic riot on Oct. 29.
item.dc:creator: Aric Toler
item.media:description: Red Wings airline planes at the airport in Makhachkala, capital of the Dagestan region in Russia.

item.title: 35 Years After Addressing Congress, James Hansen Has More Climate Warnings
item.description: The former NASA scientist James Hansen says in a new paper that global temperatures will pass a major milestone this decade, faster than other estimates predict.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: James Hansen in 2017. “The 1.5 degree limit is deader than a doornail,” he said recently.

item.title: House Passes $14.3 Billion in Aid for Israel but Leaves Out Ukraine
item.description: The Republican-led House approved $14.3 billion for Israel’s war with Hamas, tying the aid to spending cuts. The Senate plans to craft its own bill that will include aid for Ukraine and Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli armored vehicles on the border with the Gaza Strip on Tuesday. President Biden has requested $105 billion in aid for Israel and Ukraine, and other global crises.

item.title: Hezbollah’s Leader to Speak Publicly for 1st Time Since Hamas Attacked Israel
item.description: Many in the region are watching Hassan Nasrallah’s speech for insights into whether Hezbollah will escalate its battle with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Hezbollah Media Relations Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo released last week by Hezbollah’s news media office shows Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, right; Ziad Nakhale, the leader of Palestinian Islamic Jihad, center; and Saleh Al-Arouri, the deputy chief of Hamas, at an undisclosed location.

item.title: Cornell University Cancels Friday Classes After Antisemitic Threats
item.description: The university said it would take a day to allow the campus to reflect and to calm tensions after an arrest in the case.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.category: Hillel, The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life
item.media:description: Online threats against Jews and against Cornell University’s kosher’s dining room prompted university officials this week to guard the building and the school’s Center for Jewish Living next door.

item.title: A Young Woman Describes the Crisis in Gaza
item.description: Nour AlSaqqa, who is from Gaza City, has been documenting her life during the Israel-Hamas war. She said she fears that if the shortages of basic necessities persist, she will die.
item.dc:creator: Chevaz Clarke

item.title: ‘In Egypt Now. Free!’: First Evacuees From Gaza Feel Relief and Gratitude
item.description: “You feel that human beings’ lives are so worthless,” said Ala Al Husseini, 61, an Austrian-Palestinian dual national who was allowed to leave Gaza on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The first few hundred dual citizens, foreigners and their families, as well as Palestinian staff members of international organizations, were able to leave Gaza on Wednesday through its border with Egypt.

item.title: Evacuating From Gaza Is Its Own Ordeal
item.description: For many, the path to the border crossing to reach Egypt has been filled with danger.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Ameera Harouda
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up on Wednesday to check a list of names of people who were going to be allowed to cross the border into Egypt from Rafah, Gaza, on Thursday.

item.title: The West Bank seethes amid the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Smoke rising above the town of Deir Sharaf in the Nablus governorate of the occupied West Bank on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Top Commander Says War With Russia Has Hit a ‘Stalemate’
item.description: In a candid assessment, Gen. Valery Zaluzhny said no “beautiful breakthrough” was imminent and that breaking the deadlock could require advances in technological warfare.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing toward a front line in eastern Ukraine last month.

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s Fund-Raiser for Gaza Aid Raises $17 Million in Hours
item.description: The belated campaign, announced more than three weeks into the war, appeared consistent with the Saudi government’s ambivalent response to the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians waiting to buy bread in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, last week.

item.title: How a Campaign of Extremist Violence Is Pushing the West Bank to the Brink
item.description: Israeli settlers and Palestinians have been locked in a cycle of bloodshed for decades. But extremist settler attacks could send the conflict out of control.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Rami Nazzal and Adam Sella
item.media:description: Mourners bury the body of Bilal Muhammad Saleh, a Palestinian man killed by a settler in the West Bank last Saturday.

item.title: Storm Ciarán: 6 Dead as U.K. and Western Europe Lashed With Rain and Wind
item.description: With winds expected to exceed 85 miles per hour in some areas, Britain’s weather agency issued its second-highest level of alert for parts of southern England.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Dorset, England, on Thursday. The British Coast Guard warned people to “stay away from the water’s edge.”

item.title: Who Killed the Innkeeper With a Sword in 1315?
item.description: A map pinpointing hundreds of homicides in 14th-century England could help teach medieval history.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: In Shetland, the Hottest Event of the Year Stars Sheep and Knitters
item.description: The festival of the intricately crafted textiles of the Shetland Islands, a remote archipelago off Scotland’s coast, draws hundreds of knitters from around the world for all things wool.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Andrew Testa
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: Kenyan Runners Are Being Chased by a National Doping Crisis
item.description: Nearly 300 athletes from Kenya have been punished for using banned substances since 2015, tarnishing the country’s image as a running powerhouse.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.media:description: Wilson Kipsang, the New York City Marathon champion in 2014, is among the hundreds of Kenyan runners serving doping bans.

item.title: Australian Woman Charged With Murder in Suspected Mushroom Poisoning Case
item.description: In a case that has gripped Australia, three people fell ill and died soon after eating lunch at the home of a relative.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A police officer investigating with a dog at the property of Erin Patterson in Leongatha, Australia, on Thursday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: The first evacuees leave Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Foreign passport holders and their families waiting to cross the Rafah border into Egypt from Southern Gaza Strip, on Wednesday.

item.title: Colombia’s Economic Woes Push Fighters to Join Ukraine War
item.description: Hundreds of experienced fighters have joined Kyiv’s ranks to improve their financial fortunes, reflecting the recruitment struggles faced by both sides of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Isayen Herrera
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Cubillos, at home in Neiva, Colombia, holds a photograph of her husband, Manuel Barrios who was killed in Ukraine after joining Ukraine’s fight against Russia.

item.title: Student Protesters Walk Out of Hillary Clinton’s Class at Columbia
item.description: The action was in protest of what they had perceived as the school’s role in publicly shaming students who had signed a statement saying that “the Israeli extremist government” bore responsibility for the war.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman

item.title: Risk of a Wider Middle East War Threatens a ‘Fragile’ World Economy
item.description: After shocks from the pandemic and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, there’s little cushion if the fighting between Hamas and Israel becomes a regional conflict.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians displaced by the Israel-Hamas war shopping at a market in Khan Yunis in Gaza this week.

item.title: Palestinians Struggle to Reach Jabaliya Family Members After Israel Airstrike
item.description: On Wednesday, the devastated neighborhood, where local officials say dozens were killed and hundreds were wounded in a Tuesday attack, was hit again.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick and Hiba Yazbek

item.title: Hundreds Leave Gaza Strip for Egypt as Israel Closes In on Main City
item.description: Hundreds of people, including a few Americans, left the besieged territory for Egypt, the first group allowed across the border since the war began.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Foreign passport holders at the Rafah border crossing check a list to see if they were permitted to leave the Gaza Strip on Wednesday.

item.title: Shanghai’s Halloween Party, a Rare Chance for Chinese to Vent in Style
item.description: Thousands paraded the streets in creative, joyful and provocative costumes in a four-day celebration of a city returning to life.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Qian and Agnes Chang

item.title: Biden Found Even Modest Israel-Palestinian Peace Steps Impossible
item.description: A president focused on China and Ukraine had little time or inclination for a distant goal that stymied several of his predecessors.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: President Biden did not appoint a special envoy for Middle East peace or task his secretary of state with trying to forge an agreement between Israel and the Palestinians.

item.title: Israel Confirms Deaths of 15 Soldiers in Ground Invasion of Gaza
item.description: The soldiers’ deaths were the first publicly confirmed by the Israeli military inside Gaza since an invasion began on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Smoke rising above Beit Hanoun in northern Gaza on Wednesday morning after an overnight Israeli airstrike.

item.title: Frustrated Zelensky Says Ukraine’s War Effort Is Being Underestimated
item.description: As U.S. officials warned senators against halting military aid, President Volodymyr Zelensky said his troops’ achievements were “perceived as a given.”
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops during training in the Donetsk region on Saturday. Both sides have been burning through huge quantities of ammunition.

item.title: Bolivia Cuts Diplomatic Ties With Israel Over Strikes in Gaza
item.description: Chile and Colombia said they were recalling their ambassadors to Israel in light of the strikes.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians inspecting damage to a house that airstrikes destroyed in Khan Younis, a southern Gaza city, on Wednesday.
